I, Suchiguma (you may call me sushi or sushigummy if that's easier), am the main author of this website, which contains several guides and resources for Azur Lane endgame.
I specialize in crafting fleet/gear strategy for endgame PvE battles. These are some examples of my achievements:
EX: Usually top 3 EX score across EN servers.
Extreme Challenge: Auto speedruns with the world's fastest or near-fastest clear times in multiple months.
Hard Arbiter: Auto speedruns like killing each arbiter in 21 seconds using faster but lower-damage gear.
Campaign: Auto lethal 15-4 with a single fleet (no subs, no support carriers, no crossfleet).
Go back to the
Home Page
view my work.

A long, long time ago (but after EN servers' beta period), I was a clueless little new player. I found some deteriorating (and, in hindsight, often questionable) guides on the street and perused them diligently along with the EN wiki, helping me clear Chapter 12 with ease. However, as a casual player, I fell victim to mistakes such as retiring ships after level 70 MLB for the noble but misguided ideal of clearing dock space; some of the ships lost in the great purges offered key level 120 tech stats (sorry, Intrepid and Eskimo).

Sometime in late 2020, I began taking the game more seriously. I farmed 12-2 and 12-4 with a 1:3 fleet and even wrote a simulation to calculate when to retreat from 12-4 for maximum ship experience gains (this was before clearing rewards were added for completing the boss battle). However, mobilizing my account to handle the endgame content of the time proved slow, and I failed to one-shot Hiryuu META and Ark Royal META when Operation Siren released.

Fast forward a few years, and it seems I've made rather respectable progress, despite my dubious beginnings. Today, I’m hailed as one of the most eminent scholars of my field. My journey proves that I...I forgot the point of writing this story.
I hang out in the
Azur Lane Official Discord
If you have a general gameplay question that can be formulated outside the context of this website, then ask in the #gameplay-help channel there. You may or may not ping me.
If your gameplay question must mention some content in this website, then either ask in the #gameplay-help channel there but do NOT ping me, or direct message me @suchiguma.

Note that I will not accept low-effort or easy questions in DMs. My DMs are reserved for feedback or complex/important questions about my guides or content that you do not trust #gameplay-help with. Please also direct fleet-building help or dock/account help to #gameplay-help.

This guide is for first-time clearing Chapter 15 on auto in lethal threat level, with manual enemy node selection. Auto search on safe threat for farming Houston II is not covered (maybe just take 15-4 Option A and add a healer to the boss fleet).
If you have reached Chapter 15, we assume you know basic fleet building, fleet positioning, and basic game terminology like BB, AA, and ASW.
Read
wiki notes
for mechanics. Read the "Allied Support Carriers" point very carefully.

Same as in Chapter 14, X-1 and X-2 form the tutorial and X-3 and X-4 are much harder. The enemy order here is six mobs, one boss. The 15-1 boss has medium armor and the 15-2 boss has heavy armor. Both your mob and boss fleets need to contain decent ships and gear. There is nothing notable about 15-1, as it’s a tutorial to Chapter 15.
The boss in 15-2 is a double BBV boss, Ise and Hyuuga. Their shelling can delete a full HP main fleet ship in the span of three seconds. Putting a
washing machine

and EVA augment (Scepter or Officer's Sword) on your main fleet ships, especially the flagship, is strongly recommended for 15-2 only. Be prepared to quit the battle and retry. Summon submarines just before the bosses spawn, so they can help delete the bosses quicker. If you choose to manual, use airstrikes to cancel the bosses’ salvos.
Enemy submarines appear in Reconnaissance Fleets (DD nodes) in 15-3 and 15-4. Your mob fleet must bring ASW.
Technically, you could fight BB nodes and CV nodes only, but that’s certainly harder.

The enemy order in 15-3 is three mobs, medium armor first boss, two mobs, medium armor second boss. The same boss fleet you used for 15-1 and 15-2 should be able to handle the second boss. But now, your mob fleet has to deal with submarines and a tough first boss. Strongly consider shifting some better gear and/or ships to the mob fleet if your boss fleet is not struggling.
The enemy order in 15-4 is three mobs, medium armor first boss, two mobs, light armor second boss, one mob, light/medium armor third boss.

You can use either your mob fleet or your boss fleet to fight each of the three bosses. So there are 2^3 = 8 ways to assign your fleets to the bosses. This bar chart approximates how strong your mob and boss fleets need to be, for six of eight ways. The leftmost four orders are recommended, while the rightmost two are not. The chart and recommendations assume that Clearing Mode is OFF, so the Data Analyzed debuff will apply, and MMM and BBB are excluded for obvious reasons.

A very strong boss fleet fights the first and third bosses (BMB). Try to not spend more than 25% of any ship’s HP in the first boss battle. Using a healer with good damage like Volga is reasonable, but damage is still important.

The mob fleet can be about as strong as the 15-3 mob fleet. You have access to an ammo node, and the second boss is a pushover and acts as free healing if you are using two healers. The only harder parts compared to 15-3 are that enemies are one level higher and that there are two Special Aviation Fleets.
A very strong mob fleet fights all mobs, first boss, and third boss (MBM).
Since the "boss fleet" is only dealing with an easy second boss, you can add crossfleet ships to help the mob fleet. The boss fleet can look like UR BB, Independence, Perseus, tank, flex, flex.
Option B is also the most consistent strategy to defeat all mobs to get the third star on lethal threat level. To get the third star, we recommend this order.
Do NOT use the ammo node early.
Fight two Special Aviation Fleets.
Fight one more enemy. We want to prioritize Large Main Fleets while the mob fleet still has ammo. If there are none, choose a Large Air Formation or whatever is hardest.
Fight Boss 1 and then one more enemy following the same order as in Step 2. Now, the mob fleet is out of ammo. Choose a hard enemy if your fleet is healthy, otherwise choose an easy enemy.
Use the "boss fleet" for Boss 2.
Reserve two Medium or Large Reconnaissance fleets and Boss 3 until the end. Use your mob fleet to fight everything else.
Pick up the full 3 ammo node, clear the last two Reconnaissance fleets to hopefully heal up, and clear Boss 3.
Recommendation: If you can't three star on lethal, then don't. Safe threat level gives your fleet like +20% damage dealt and -36% damage taken.
Mob fleet: UR BB, 2 healer CV/CVLs, tank, flex, flex.
Boss fleet: UR BB, 2 damage CV/CVLs, tank, flex, flex.
The flex slots should not be squishy and should contribute survivability, AA, and/or damage. Add ASW in the 15-3/15-4 mob fleet. Good ships can contribute two or three or even four of these.
You
can

bring a single healer like Unicorn for the mob fleet, but it adds inconsistency and makes recovering from suicide boat leaks or submarine leaks extremely difficult. Solo healer is great when your fleet is very strong, but if you have a great fleet and account then you're winning with or without a second healer anyways.

For the boss fleet damage carriers, you may use a semi-preload like Independence or Impero to deal with the pre-boss waves quicker. These two also have strong damage for the boss anyways. If you use two normal-reload carriers, then try to desync them.

Carrier level, AVI, and RLD matter. Affinity affects AVI and RLD. You should get all support carriers to at least level 120 and Love affinity because Chapter 15 is not the place to be cutting corners at. The equipped fighter and the fighter enhancement level matter. The DB or TB can be any enhancement level and any plane, just have gold or rainbow for +45 or +65 avi stat.
Assuming all have equal level, affinity, and gear etc., the best support fleet carriers are, in
slightly

decreasing order of strength: Fritz Rumey much stronger, Hwah Jah (Retrofit), Nakhimov (REQUIRES DEV 30), Indomitable, Implacable, Illustrious, Illustrious µ, Chen Hai (Retrofit), Little Illustrious, Langley (Retrofit), Yorktown II, Independence, Albion, Centaur.
Slightly
means slightly; it's ok to use a more accessible ship lower on the list.
The best support fighter is
Flapjack
, followed by the much cheaper and still effective
Skyrocket
and
fw190a5
. All three of these are in Gear Lab. If you are on a budget, prioritize Flapjacks for the surface fleets, and fill the support fleet with Skyrocket or fw190a5.
They are all similar, pick any three SR subs. Many bonus points for high oxygen, some bonus points for fleet synergy.
Use Improved Snorkel on everyone.
Use any mix of
Bidder
G7e
, or
Type 95 Kai
, or use six of the same, it doesn’t matter.
Submarines should be used on all boss battles (but optional for 15-4’s second boss), so reserve ammo for those. Spend the other ammo on out-of-ammo battles or the Special Aviation Fleet.
Avoid: summoning submarines at the beginning of a battle.

Summoning submarines early in battle means that they surface and die. Summon them 20 to 40 seconds into the battle so that you win before they run out of oxygen. You know roughly how long your battles take.
If you haven’t been playing Operation Siren, you probably won’t win in Chapter 15. Lots of the best gear is in Gear Lab, and +13 gear is a huge boost in strength.
Bring Hedgehog and at least one other ASW weapon on the mob fleet for 15-3 and 15-4. Options include a gold ASW plane or purple ASW plane on a CVL, a purple depth charge, or Eldridge (Retrofit).

Auxes: standard auxes, but vanguard ships (especially if the middle slot is not a DD) can use anti-torpedo bulges if they are not occupied with ASW.

Use cats, they do not have to be perfect. Random level 30 cats boost your fleet by 10-20%. Important talents: mountain on mob = flame when out of ammo > flame when with ammo = mountain on boss > other stuff.
Use double line or circular formation, never single line, depending on how good your fleet’s AA is.
Kill the enemy Special Aviation Fleet at the beginning of each sortie.
Avoid Large/Medium Main Fleets. If you're 3 starring, use Shimanto and/or Musashi, and never fight them when out of ammo.

The cores and experience stones needed to craft and upgrade unique augments are time-gated. Currently, it is impossible to have crafted and maxed all unique augments released in the game. Meta-chasing and new players need to choose carefully which ships to craft augments for. Thus, this augment module tier list was made to rate the effectiveness and worth of each augment to help you make those decisions.
Read the
Augmentation
wiki page for how to get, upgrade, and use augments.

content.html:
Expand to see the rubric.

Gain

Gain for unique augments rates the overall benefit the augment brings to the ship over a generic purple augment (or no augment, for ships who can't use purple augments). This includes damage, survivability, buffing, and everything. The relative strength of the ship does not matter; a +50% damage boost for a weak ship should be rated the same as a +50% damage boost for a strong ship.

Worth

Worth is subjective. If you must use a waifu no matter what, then of course her augment would be very much worth. So the "worth" ratings in the table roughly follows this rubric:
  • Has sizeable gain for a ship who sees various endgame use.
  • Has sizeable gain for a ship who is good in at least some endgame content and has few other substitutes.
  • Makes the ship useful for midgame to lategame.
  • Makes the ship decent but not meta.
  • Worse than or equal to purple augments, or the augmented ship would still be bad.

New SKK

Rates "worth" for new players, covering your first two or three unique augments or until you reach "midgame" (farming Chapter 12 or beating Abyssal zones). Obviously, do not craft the unique augment of a ship you don't own.... This tier list should not force you to obtain a ship.
  • The most important in helping a new player reach midgame.
  • Very helpful for a new player to reach midgame.
  • Good to have as a new player but maybe a bit out of order.
  • Diverts resources away from far more important augments or outlives its usefulness quickly.
  • Simply a waste of augment resources for a new player.

Collabs

Collab augments are cheaper to max level, and this cheapness is included in both "worth" ratings for all players and for new players. If an old collab augment is said to be worth for new players, obviously new new players can't get them (or the ships) anymore. So it is just there for new players who got the ship and augment, then quit the game and recently returned.

content.text: Note: New players should save up for impactful unique augments instead of crafting or upgrading blue/purple augments.

Each month's page will have strategies and several example fleets. Although we try to be detailed in strategies and provide multiple example fleets, we do not know what ships or gear you have. Treat the example fleets as examples, and consider your own better upgrades or close substitutes.
Warning: Do not treat examples as requirements. New Jersey's presence in an example fleet is not an endorsement for using UR bulins on her.

We assume Hard (Augur) difficulty, but the same strategies usually work for lower difficulties with worse fleets and gear. We also assume auto battle only, because most of the difficult CM gimmicks are nullified by proper manualing.
Always check boss stats and skills on
Extreme Challenge
wiki (or in game, but sometimes the game says a wrong number).
Tip: Fleet screenshots using
Azur Lane Fleet Tool
show the vanguard from bottom (main-tank) to top (off-tank). It's like the in-game Formation screen but rotated counter-clockwise. The ships are also marked with 1, 2, and 3 from bottom to top.

Most CM's are exercises in reading and timing. Oaths or exact gear levels (+10 to +13) are not required unless for timing. However, many example fleets are timing-sensitive, and you often won't have the exact ships, oaths, gear, cat RLD, and RLD tech to copy them correctly. Then, you will need to calculate your own fleet timing. To the best of our knowledge,
this online calculator
henceforth referred to as "the calculator"
, is the only one that is precise enough for these CM timing calculations. We highly recommend not being scared by it and learning how to use it on desktop.

If an example fleet requires "50 CV RLD with oath", that means you need oathed CVs and have CV reload from tech + cats = 50. Alternatively, it would also probably work without oaths and with CV tech + cats = 57 or 58.

Due to how the game code loop works, some boss skills, boss movement patterns, or ship skills can be delayed by 0.0s to 0.1s every time. This is more noticeable in long battles like the game mode this guide is for. Some strategies attempt to account for this delay, but sometimes it can't be fixed.

This month is a straight DPS and reading check. Light status = shielded = healing 1% HP per second. Dark status = easy mode. Bring vanguard ships that spam a lot of shells to break the shield as fast as possible, because you do not want to let Katsuragi heal 15% HP for every 30% lost. Other than the vanguard shell spam, there are no other gimmicks, so bring typical good anti-medium DPS. We only provide examples of fleets with good synergy and sync to attain high DPS. If you do not know how to set up high DPS fleets in the absence of boss gimmicks by yourself, we recommend asking or lurking in
ALO Discord
#gameplay-help.
Note: Katsuragi's movement cycle is approximately 28.45s long, so you should bring your own slow/freeze.

Although Katsuragi's skill descriptions imply that the five rotating shields can each block 70 shells, in reality they share the same hit count. So if 70 shells each hit any of the shields, all five shields disappear, and Katsuragi enters Dark status. Furthermore, like typical rotating shields, her shields will not block arcing shells from BB guns, CB guns, torpedos, and bombs. Katsuragi also often moves back to the far right of the screen (as 13-4 Taihou does when carpet bombing).
Taking this information into consideration, some example favored and unfavored things are listed here:
Things that are good against Katsuragi.
Twin 138.6mm and both Twin 130mm's have high range and shells per second.
Twin 100mm Kai has high shells per second and spams barrages, but is more inconsistent due to low range.
Plymouth has 3 main gun mounts (MGMs) and a guaranteed aimed barrage every 10s.
San Diego and Scylla spam shells and have good AA to keep carriers concealed, though Sandy's augment barrage ignores shields.
Helena has 2 CL MGMs and 1 DD mount.
Barrage or MGM spammers like Mogador, Harbin, Tai Yuan > other DDGs, or Tashkent(s).
Things that may be good in general but are less so against Katsuragi.
Triple 155mm Kai or any other slow gun.
CA guns have low shells per second.
CBs (and basically all CAs) have poor shield-breaking capabilities, and their tankiness is not needed.
Hindenburg's guns ignore shields.
Z52's barrages pass through shields, and she only has 1 MGM.

Tempesta submarine frigates can also help break one shield cycle. Summon them a few seconds before you will pass the 30% HP difference since Katsuragi last had shields. Just put cheap gear, no need to spend core data on all the 12-pounders and Round Shots.

This fleet won in 9:58 with half tech, mid cats, and no submarine fleet. Please bring submarines and a bit more +13 or tech. Fritz is not using double BF109G because that would make her too fast. To keep Fritz before AvP, do not exceed 50 CV RLD, but get as high as you can so that Fritz stays synced for longer. Enterprise will desync eventually but not much we can do about it. San Diego may sink after 8 or 9 minutes - level 125 is very important to extend her lifetime.
None. Even the
High-End BB
fleet will take over 6 minutes with half tech and mid cats. Try your best to copy it and make substitutes.

This fleet won in 4:52 with half tech, mid cats, and no subs. For this specific gear and oaths, Nakhimov syncs with Soyuz at 56 CV RLD and 17 BB RLD, or you can subtract an equal amount of RLD from both CVs and BBs (but you lose Helena sync if you subtract too much). Don't forget to decrease your CV tech to use cats with CV RLD. Flandre gun was chosen to keep Helena sync. You may also use
Champagne gun
with 45 CV RLD and 17 BB RLD.
Calculator Link

This month is a difficult vanguard DPS check. The Jug has 120k HP, 100 EVA, 0 LUCK, and 300 AA. So your vanguard needs to do 2400 damage per second, with a 1.5s starting grace period to do the first 2400 damage whenever the Jug spawns.

This is quite difficult because you can't rely on torpedos, barrages, and long-reload CA guns to do damage consistently (the game calls it "Recurring" damage so we will too). Another pain point is when Newcastle goes in front of the Jug to eat up your vanguard's non-piercing shells, or when Newcastle is above or below the Jug and gets targeted.
Plymouth gun
and
Mogador gun
are highly recommended, but other older AP DD/CL guns are weaker by a lot and not worth using over good HE guns.

Some main fleet ships with 10s attacks or long-range aux guns can also help add recurring damage. Examples include Ulrich, Fritz, Saratoga, or Rupprecht. Submarines or Tempesta IXs can also help for 40s to 60s.
Warning: If your vanguard can't do enough DPS, then don't use low-damage (de)buffers like Aurora, Sirius, or Helena.

But vanguard DPS isn't the whole story. Killing the Jug only gives a 6s window for your main fleet to do full damage to Newcastle, so your main fleet also needs to be synced. Unfortunately for CVs, which require rockets to be good against light armor, having three tightly synced CVs means that some rockets will kill the Jug, some more rockets will hit the water where the Jug was, and only a few rockets will target Newcastle after the Jug dies. Hence, despite the enemy's low AA of 300, CVs are difficult to use. CVs are still better than BBs here if used well with high investment, but that will not be the main focus of this guide.
This fleet won in 8:39 with mid cats, half tech, and no submarine fleet.

This is a difficult month, so the the fleet should be stronger than the usual "mid". This fleet has semi-high vanguard DPS. But because Plymouth's gun is the only piercing weapon, Ulrich may or may not be needed to help do recurring damage to the Jug. Block Soyuz behind Vanguard, but note that giving Soyuz a Mk7 and Vanguard a Mk6 would not be ideal for sync, so give them the same gun. Also, Ulrich needs to avoid the Mk6/Mk7 reload speed so that she doesn't permanently block Soyuz.
This fleet won in 6:18 with mid cats, half tech, and no submarine fleet.

Bismarck Zwei is highly recommended for more than one reason, but it is still brute force-able with other rainbow BBs. This fleet and similar fleets should work with any BB RLD or oaths. We mention this every month - block the faster BBs behind the slower BB with unequal
AFCT
HSFCR
usage. But this month, Biszwei should go first to pull the Jug and Newcastle together, so we give Soyuz an autoloader to make her reload faster than Biszwei.

Because these rainbow BBs don't contribute recurring damage besides Bisz's Geryon every other salvo, the vanguard absolutely needs to have high DPS. Bisz is flag to get Plymouth's buff because Bisz does the most damage by far. Z52's debuff only applies when the above-flag BB fires, so Bisz's first volley of each salvo won't get it. But it's a minor loss, and Plymouth and Z52 are both still worth using.
Wait, 2 BB 1 CV counts as a CV fleet? Too bad, take it or leave it. There aren't enough high-damage carriers who can stagger to make a real strategy for CVs.

The firing order is Bisz, then Soyuz, then Nakhimov. Bisz and Nakhimov should have the same reload time, only Bisz has -15% first load time. The BBs kill the Jug, then Nakhimov's rockets target Newcastle. Soyuz should fire after Bisz so that she can hit both targets, and so that her slow persists until Nakhimov's payload hits. If Soyuz's barrage activates too early, then Nakhimov may not get her +40% crit damage. That's why Soyuz in this example has an autoloader that's higher than +0 but not too high.

Bisz is once again ideal. Another UR BB can work, but if she and Soyuz fail to kill the Jug, then Nakhimov's airstrike is wasted. Bisz allows Nakhimov to splash both the Jug and Newcastle with high probability even if the Jug is still alive.
calculator link
This video copies a similar strategy from 2024. Bisz pulls the Jug and Newcastle together, and Yorkii rockets them. Kearsarge does her own thing because she's really slow.

Not much strategy, just have high tech/gear/cats. Enterprise can be faster or slower than Yorkii, doesn't really matter. But we would guess that Enterprise being faster is better in this case, so that her rockets don't hit the water every time. There is a lot of lost potential because you kill the Jug at random times, and whether another main fleet ship attacks Newcastle in the next 6s is up to chance. Brute force is brute force.

Fritz is an upgrade over Enterprise. Fritz contributes recurring damage and does a lot more damage than a 70% Enterprise. Just make sure to give Fritz and Yorkii slightly different reload times with a difference of at least 0.25s, say.
Someone won in 6:27 with Kear Yorkii Fritz, full +10 gear. But try it yourself.

This is a CM that can be very annoying due to various sources of lag and RNG. However, do not be scared by the double Hard
. If you time Unicorn precisely, then the Tank check is naturally solved. Or if you bring tanks and Perseus, then Perseus trivializes the timing precision.

You must either bring a vanguard heal that activates every 20s, or have carriers that reload slightly faster than 20s for a screen clear. Toolkits alone will not do the job. The best ways to get the heal are
Primary Healers (Recommended)

Unicorn, who has the benefit of doing more damage and healing than Perseus. Must be timed properly, 19.92s-19.93s probably works for 5-7 minutes, and 19.94s-19.96s probably works for 10 minutes. For a level 125 Unicorn in love,
BF-109G
and
Ryuusei
is 19.95s in-game with 2 RLD tech (also try 3 RLD if 2 doesn't work), or use
HVARcat
and
Ju-87d
with 0 RLD tech.
Do not bring cats with CVL RLD.
Passing the first few stings relies on RNG, because if your vanguard is too close to the boss then they'll get hit before Unicorn heals.

Perseus, who suffers from low damage and lower healing. She struggles to keep a sandwiched Aurora alive, so Eldridge is needed. A Plymouth-Aurora-Eldridge vanguard can survive for 7 minutes, which may not be enough time if your main fleet is weak. Furthermore, if her heal lags less than Elbing's sting, then Perseus can cleanse your vanguard of venom right before Scorpion's Mist (which lasts for 2s) expires. If your ships are moving, they regain the venom by touching Scorpion's Mist.
Minor Healers (not recommended due to how much damage the boss does)
Little Formidable requires >90% HP, so to avoid her being burnt, bring at least one non-concealed main fleet ship, or pray with a full carrier fleet.
Marseillaise for a full-French vanguard.
Boise μ with a level 8 healing skill.
Ognevoy has a 10s heal, but she desyncs after like 5 minutes due to activating 4x as much as Elbing's skill.

Due to a possible bug, similarly to Cancer (Graf Spee), most vanguard ships get the +60% damage buff permanently, even if they get healed. Ships who gain, lose, or refresh another source of damageRatioBullet, like Bayard or Bremerton, lose the free +60% damage until the next venom mist. First, read the boss skills if you haven't. You must consistently interrupt Warspite every 20s, and not mentioned is that her charge attack has 30k HP and finishes in 5s. Let "success" denote your fleet successfully interrupting Warspite by dealing enough damage. Let "failure" denote the opposite. Generally, a success causes your main fleet to lose a little HP, and a failure causes it to lose a LOT of HP. Do not expect to tank two or more failures.

On average, the charge attack happens every ~20.05s, and Warspite stops for ~8.2s (shown in the chart below) every ~20.45s. Strategies that attempt to take advantage of her stop should consider that timing attacks to her charge attack will become desynced with her stop later in the battle.

One recurring strategy you will find in the following fleets is a BB (excluding Alsace) or Unzen with 20s reload time. After one failure, Warspite will blind your fleet, preventing torpedos, airstrikes, and main fleet salvos from launching. The blindness ends around the same time Warspite begins the next charge. Since BBs and Unzen cannot begin reloading the next attack while holding one, they will become synced with Warspite's charging for the rest of the battle.
Unfortunately, this CM is hard. Try your best to copy one of the High-End fleets with Helena, and manual for clearing barrages or hitting stop times if you need to.

The least-effort strategy that may randomly lose even when geared well. The BBs have no sync whatsoever, so they fire at arbitrary times, with UvH offering frequent salvos. Every 20s, pray that at least one BB's salvo partially falls within the 5s charge attack window, and some high-DPS vanguard ships can also help reach the 30k threshold. The fleet is expected to get a few interrupt failures, so you should also pray that your BBs evade enough shells.

In fleets with non-concealed ship(s), Warspite will fire additional AP barrages at your main fleet ships, especially Musashi or the flagship. These barrages chip away your BBs' HP, so it is a DPS race. If you don't have three good vanguard ships like Eldridge, Aegir, Plymouth, Unzen, Hindenburg, Guam, or Helena, then you could try putting a ship with Flank Defense or Flagship Cover.
If you put in more effort, you can try to get Unzen's torpedos or one of the BBs to have around 20s reload time. Then, the fleet will win more consistently.

Because carriers (except Impero) can store airstrikes, being blinded once by Warspite will not sync the 20s carriers to the charge attack. Therefore, these fleets must rely on the vanguard to deal 30k damage in 5s. If you can get the vanguard damage to work, then ~20s CVs with Helena should produce the fastest possible clear times.
Warning: Unzen's 20.0s to 20.1s (improved) quad mag torpedos are basically required.
